I've given it a thumbs up, but not listing the pros for now, only areas which I believe should be prioritized imo:

#1 Low hanging fruit: The game desperately needs some ambience sound FX like birds, wind etc. It's not gonna be a simulation in the end so atmosphere will be paramount. Our group actually played bird songs with Alexa in order to have some amience. Check out Hunter Call of the Wild for inspiration.

Also:
- Vehicle handling is just awful..the Quad is next to unusable
- there is no walk function, just run and sprint. Kills atmosphere a bit.
- trees are one-hitted independent of size. Seems like a deliberately decision but a few more hits would help with the atmosphere and sense of satisfaction.
- footsteps are always the same sound, no matter the surface.
- It should be possible to sit on furniture.
- The rooster should go "COCK-A-DOODLE-DOO" :)

Big Pro: The character generation is great.

I had a hard time getting into this game because after the tutorial quests there nothing, it's like, "have fun kiddo! The world is your oyster." 
Don't get me wrong, I became addicted to building my ranch but I equally got frustrated quickly over the clunky controls and the emptiness of the world and the lack of info in the store in regards to using tools.
I spent 5 minutes trying to put deer meat through my meat grinder, but apparently you can't use it for wild game. No where anywhere does it say this.   Finding eggs is hard, they're so small and get lost in the grass. Having to pick up tiny chicken poops piece by piece? tedious, and when your character pivots their stance or a hen walks in your way you have to TRY AGAIN. HOLD E TO REMOVE. 
Demolishing things you've built should give you at least some materials back. Reloading your gun takes an eternity when it actually happens. If you have your gun in your hands you can't get in your vehicle until you unequip it, this killed me MULTIPLE times.  I'd love to see more customisation for the ranch itself. Decorations, paint for buildings, flower beds, maybe some birds in the sky? A large map, with a huge empty lake, insanely fast deer, bears and wolves that don't give you any sort of skin or pelt when you hunt them. I also made almost an hour or progress and the game crashed and I lost it, twice. yes, twice. save often. 
I'm aware it's a work in progress, I'm extremely excited to see where it goes. As it stands it doesn't really feel worth 30$, but as it improves or when it goes on sale I recommend it to people who love mindless, grindy games like farming sim.

Overall very good steady Gameplay. There is some fine tuning,for instance sell points, tutorial, and in-game goals vs reward. However, it is a good alternative to FS19 you don't get quite the same "build mode", but who likes mundane, you do need to remember an access code in order to pick up where you left off, but this appears to be temporary as it is still an Early Acess Game. UPDATE( 1/19/22 ): So my biggest complaints are to do with how the game is advertised and the actual gameplay itself. We all know there are variations when it comes to marketing and actual programming, but there are a few things I would clarify to those considering this game as a viable future purchase. It is more of a homestead than a "Ranch" you aren't quite getting the "in town" gameplay. As mentioned before it has qualities similar to FS where a farm may actually be right in the middle of a suburb, this is a ranch and the whole purpose of the inherited home is to destroy it. Sucks, but an interesting way to give a tutorial all the same. My critique at this point for future updates would be; Better character customization, we all have a basic look, but it's hard to roleplay or simulate when your character is wearing a t-shirt and sneakers, second give us different options than a simple start to finish (yes I realize this is still pre-realease), Sandbox please I learn more from sandbox than a tutorial.

This game has a lot of potential!
It's super early access right now, you can tell within the first few days that there's a lot of work yet to be done. But despite that, it is REALLY fun. I got about 20 hours of gameplay with two friends, the other 13 hours were just me having fun and relaxing. It's a really great game to relax in, just go through the motions of caring for your animals, it's really nice.
I'd recommend playing with a group, as things are a lot more fun with friends, and it doesn't seem too balanced for singleplayer yet. It's difficult to manage everything with just one person.
I hope in the future there would be some more QoL features and maybe some upgrades to horses, specifically. Killing a meat producing animal and having to manually pick up each individual piece of meat is horrible, then having to process that piece by piece, it gets old. I found the cows to be the most fun to care for, milking is a lot more fun than picking up thirty pieces of meat.
Additionally, the horses were kind of disappointing. They're super expensive to work up towards, but hold no real practical value. And training them is just riding for hours and jumping over the same two jumps. They can't carry anything on their back, and you can't shoot off their back either. It'd be nice if they were practical to take hunting, or small errand trips, or something. Right now, they're just very time intensive things. They cost more than a car, and can do way less. I haven't managed to sell one yet because the time it takes to train them is really bothersome.

Despite all that, this game has super potential! Especially being a multiplayer ranch game. I'm really excited to see what the devs do in the future and what all is brought to the table, and I super look forward to an eventual horse overhaul!

I wish making money wasn't so time consuming, especially just starting out. All you have for making money is selling eggs and hunting and for me the only animal that spawns for hunting is deer. So i wish there were other ways to make money, like jobs or something but other than that i have really been enjoying the game.

Don't usually play simulation games, but since I saw in a gameplay video that there were quests, I figured I'd give it a try.

Pros:
* the tutorial is a fair introduction into the absolute basic things you can do, BUT you will have to figure out everything else out on your own
* starts you off with quests, so that you have direction
* some RL mechanics for the animals, but none for the rancher
* seem to be able to farm wood from anywhere on the map
* aside from some awkward moments where clicking did not pick up items, there are so far very few bugs
* buildings don't appear to take damage over time or from weather effects
* character is fairly customizable... though like, but why?
* game is in early access right now, so there may be more in the works.

Cons:
* the tutorial ends abruptly after it has you demolish a building, which for some people might be fine, but there are advanced mechanics I would have liked to have learned about through a quest line. I prefer a little guidance, which is why I don't play sim games often. 
* animals die seemingly without cause and not certain how to avoid that. only a couple of days in, despite having a coop and fence built, water and food in the trough.
* have no idea how to make chicks hatch, even though I bought a rooster. the hens don't seem particularly motherly, and there is no plan for nests or heat lamps.
* driving is controlled by both the mouse and the keyboard. at the same time.
* endless winter for me. would be nice to be able to choose climate maps at start.
* basic plans for barn require metal... and I have no idea where to get that because the tutorial doesn't cover it and I haven't seen a pickaxe for sale
* demo takes FOREVER because each little piece has to be broken down in a specific order. tedious.
* can't repair anything already on the ranch, and you don't recover any materials when you demo something.
* can't move your built items like fences and coops. only option is to demolish, which also doesn't recover any materials
* custom building pieces are limited and very few blueprints. not much styling options, either, just paint.
* no minimap for driving, nor overhead map for planning ranch out
* bird feed bag is wildly expensive and you will go through it faster than you can recover costs.
* too hard to get going. I wanted to build and sim and play with a ranch, not play a weird survival game where I often can't sell anything fast enough to replenish my stock or feed anything.

Overall, I'm sad to say this game wasn't for me. But again, I don't like open-ended simulator games. I need at least a small amount of direction (which the tutorial gave perfectly with a generic 'do this, repair that' quest line) throughout the game to keep myself busy. I already have to organize and prioritize my workload to an exhausting degree in my real life. No way I'm going to enjoy a game that makes me keep doing that when I'm supposed to be having fun and chilling out. And for a building game, I just expected a bit more ease to grow the ranch. That said, it is in early access, so perhaps people like me will find there is more to guide them at full release.

Some details for the devs : 
Sometimes reloading takes a long time to start
Placing fences can be frustrating, when trying to line it up or to connect two building with the wrong distance
Placing things in the trunk can be frustrting, as the rotation doesn,'t allow things to be precisely places and the axis can be different when the car moves.
Also, in multiplayer people don't always have the same placing / rotation axis
When building houses, if you place it not on the right angle you won't be able to place tables/stuff correctly, it won't ever line up (OCD is killing me)
There was only the 1600$ pickup truck that required to remove the brake before driving, dunno if it's normal
IT GETS LAGGY, i have a i5-10000k something and a 1070, the more you place down thing, and the more details, the laggier it gets. I don't regret making my own house last, it gets almost unplayable for the friend joining (I have an ok-ish fiber connecion)
Not being able to move things we place down, like the cheese and sausage stockage (when moving houses it gets expesive)
and / or not getting anything back while removing stuff, like a third / half the buildong cost of the said object 

Hopes for the next update : 
More car customisation, like wheels, bi-colours, and maybe add a level of dirtiness to the cars ? The more you drive the dirtiest it gets and we can have a power washer to clean it or go to the garage?
More seasons, only winter can be funkilling especially when during a storm and you can't see/hear a thing (and upping the gama makes the lights horrible)
A "farming" aspect, maybe ? It might be less ranch but growing some crops for the sausages or cheese, some herbs, and hence adding a lot more cooking
The ability to build anywhere, we wanted to zone out the road and we couldn't place fences so we kept going the wrong way
Oh and the built-in lights (i.e. houses) are horrendous, the one you can make are much better

Outside of some serious optimization issues, this game is a true attempt at a ranch simulator.

A realistic depiction of ranch life with immersive graphics and animations, as well as functions.

You are free to build all over a large ranch with the goals of the next projects completion driving you onwards. You start off real slow with some basic chickens but things start to escalate once you get your first few pigs, get into meat processing, then on to cows ect. 

Its worth mentioning that the multiplayer is perfectly implimented outside of some network glitches that can cause a dysynch after some time of playing on the same session.

The only issue with the game is its optimization when animals start to populate - which as you might of guessed - is sort of the point of having a ranch. I had 144 fps at the start but once we get several structures erected and around 30-40 chickens the game thinks 20-30 fps is fine on higher end machines with medium graphics on.

There are plenty of simulator games out there but this is the a better one. Now is this better than one of those farming/rpg games that have been popular in the last few years? In all honesty probably not, the animal interactions are essentially none other than move them for transport. Its strictly buisness, which some might like. Hopefully as the game develops we will see it evolve, god bless this ranch oh mighty.

Ranch Simulator has great potential. I've been playing it for 37 hours and having a lot of fun. I can't wait for those goats and sheep to become part of game play and I do have some important notes for the developers. 
A. I got this game about a week and a half ago and I don't even know what it looks like without the snow. Since weather doesn't really have an affect on anything, you should really let players decide what they feel like experiencing in every given moment. This was a nice idea but seriously you guys are getting so much negative feedback on it - Don't do that again :-)
B. I've fenced the entire farm like I imaging many others did - I'd like an electric automatic gate to be installed at the entrance or even a big wooden one. Right now If I want to build one I have to use the simple wooden one I use with the fences I build. I don't want to give up on the big arch.
C. There’s no such thing as a farm without a livestock guardian dog. Such dog could be released with the animals, guard them and make sure nothing comes near. If you want to go even further, have also shepherd dogs who lead the animals back to the barn when told to.
D. Horses should definitely have a breeding system. They are very cool. Also will be cool if we can take off their saddle. 
E. Seriously the whole empty town with no NPCs creeps anyone out at some point. Not to mention the Zombie lady sitting at the desk in the general store without moving. 
F. I’d push a little more recovery time for mothers in the farm before they get pregnant again. I’d even consider having some method for deciding a female will not get pregnant for now, like some kind of a birth control for when you don’t really want to separate males from females.  
G. Chickens who have fertile eggs should just sit on them. It’s tiring picking up eggs and checking them out not to mention how annoying it is when the mothers attack you and won’t let go. 
H. Is there a way for me to just allow other players to enter the farm? It’s getting lonely out there 😊

Thanks for a great game, can’t wait to see what you do next

Interesting game so far, but has a ways to go. It gets boring pretty fast at the stage it's at right now, which I get it's still early access and an early build which is why I'm not being hard on it and would sooner just sit on it for now and wait for more content. Some minor bugs here and there including getting flung the hell around if im standing in the wrong place while closing a coop door or flipping my car back over. But let me tell you that is prime entertainment for my friends to watch when I'm streaming it to them. Hopefully the chickens get a sleep animation soon because it's a little creepy looking in there and seeing that they've completely frozen in place during the night because apparently they're sleeping. The house really has no point to it yet. Do not build it. You really don't need it probably. It's just heavy on resources for no use aside from looks.

Implement a single player mode maybe. No matter if you're playing alone or with others, you can't pause the game. Now, if I'm playing alone, I would like the option to get up and go afk for a while without the risk of letting a day pass because my game doesn't pause since the esc menu behaves like I was in multiplayer with others. 

The only big thing I have a gripe with is that price tag. While it's still in early access and really not offering a lot, I don't think it should be regularly priced at 24.99. It has potential as a simulator-cost game eventually when it has more to offer, but right now it's not exactly the 25 USD type of fulfilling and mind-numbingly distracting gameplay I'm usually oddly willing to pay to have in simulator games. Not yet.

Anxious save simulator is more like it.

Don't crash, and don't die unexpectedly because when you do, your progress will be gone.  You can save yourself a little bit of a head ache by purchasing an air mattress, which you can take anywhere and use anytime, but it goes in the back of your truck instead of just being a feature that allows you to press a simple button to save.  To me, it's clunky design.

When you purchase items at the store they show up on the ground outside and you have to put it all in the back of your truck, things like ammo, which are VERY small compared to anything else you buy can be hard to spot, and honestly should just end up on your character after buying.  Everything else I was happy to put into my truck myself, but the ammo is just silly.  

The game is pretty much a hunting simulator after you run out of quests to do in order to keep your chickens fed, and gas in your sawmill and car.  It feels hard to get ahead in single player, and there seems to be a lack of easy to find wildlife in order to keep yourself going.  The animals I found in most abundance were Deer but they are fast, so you end up chasing after them for awhile, and when they die you have to take the pieces of meat ONE BY ONE to your vehicles cooler, WHAT?!  Why not let us carry more back to our cooler, what would be the harm?

The gas and the chicken feed get depleted too fast IMO.  I'm constantly going back and forth to the store and to the gas station for the game to feel like fun and not a chore, at least in single player. 

Snapping building pieces in the game is obnoxious. Enough said here I think.

The store menu items should have info about them when you hover over it with your mouse.

What I'd like to see happen is the wildlife to be more plentiful, more quests to break up the monotony of doing the same tasks over and over again, Better balancing, auto save, better guns and ammo, props and decor items.

I wouldn't recommend this game right now, but I feel it does have potential if they can fix some of these things I mentioned above.

Ranch Simulator is an easy go to game when you want to mindlessly unwind. It is a simple yet entertaining game that effortlessly draws you in to spending hours upon hours tending to your ranch and slowly building up a nice little empire of wealth. 
 
Character customisation is not a main focus of this game, however there is an adequate range of customisations to select from with regards to the basic physical features. One criticism is that, if the player takes their time with customisation, they face an issue in which the game becomes night despite being in the character creation menu drastically impeding visibility which is not ideal when customising a character's visual appearance. 
 
Despite a good range of vehicles, sadly driveability is poor with regards to vehicle handling. Thankfully vehicles can be reset to their upright position and damage is not a factor within the game at this time. The vehicles, and game mechanics itself allow for a large number of items to be transported even with the smaller vehicles if the player is mindful of placement when stacking. It should be noted that the limit is maintained regardless with animals as these cannot be stacked on one another. 
 
The game offers an average building component to the game, in which there are a number of premade structures to select from as well as the option to create free form buildings. Presently these building are relatively basic, however serve the intended purpose. The premade home structures once completed come fully furnished with interactable items which are a nice addition. Although lighting within the homes could be improved, there is the option to add lights in through the building tool however these are unflattering. Some obstacles were faced when attempting to build, specifically the ability to align and snap fences. As such it is difficult to make these straight and to have these align well with premade structures. 
 
Whilst there are wild animals included within the terrain, these are mostly lacking in not only quantity but variety with long respawn times. From the initial game trailer, it could be presumed the game would include more hunting however this was not the case. It does appear as though this may be an avenue pursued by the game developers, with a building off in the mountains with an NPC surrounded by mounted animal heads and weapons. Currently these are not yet interactable in this building. Whilst players would benefit from more wild animals to hunt in early game play, this would also be an interesting and fun addition to late game play if wild animals occasionally ventured closer to the ranch requiring players to better protect their livestock. 
 
The game includes a range of animals that you can breed and farm for produce such as chickens, pigs, and most recently cows which are either targeted towards being farmed for meat or for the purpose of producing milk. When owning and tending to a variety of these animals, the player is kept busy with a variety of tasks to complete such as tending to the barns/stables, upkeep with food and water supplies, and of course collecting the produce specific to that animal type. A few issues were noted here, firstly it is highly important to keep the animal population (specifically the pigs) at a manageable level. Over population of animals dramatically impedes playability by causing severe frame rate drops and lag. Secondly, all animals within the game appear to be programmed to automatically beeline for the door/barn gate when opened, making it incredibly difficult and frustrating to move animals whilst keeping others in their current barn. Additionally, moving animals around is made further difficult due to collision with other items, specifically other animals. These issues with animal movement are mostly notable with pigs and cows, as chickens can be easily moved and relocated by picking the animal up. 
 
In addition to obtaining produce either through collecting eggs, milking cows or harvesting pigs/cows for meat, the player can further their profits and game play by crafting more advanced food types such as cheese, meatballs, or sausages that can either be sold raw, cooked or as dried salami. The cooking aspect is a nice addition that again allows another component of game play to alternate amongst the other tasks. However, there is no clear indication of recipes per se in regards to the kinds of food you can make. A recipe book would be a great addition to this game to provide clearer direction and options in the available food types that can be crafted. More food options to craft would also be a nice addition, with potential herbs and spices an option to be purchased from the general store. Further to this, it would be interesting to see the game developers include a cooking skill concept within the game, in which the more you craft food, the higher your skill level in this area resulting in a faster crafting time rewarding the progression in this area.
 
Whilst the game runs well a few errors were encountered during game play. There are a few notable movement glitches with the characters, specifically if two characters are getting up from the same bed/sleep location at the same time, causing one to be propelled into the air. Another issue identified with movement is noted within the house, specifically going up and down the stairs causing the character to become stuck in midair, although this is easily fixed or entirely avoided if the character stares directly at the floor when walking down the stairs. The final movement glitch worth mentioning appears to occur when exiting a vehicle prematurely prior to it coming to a complete stop, causing the character to glitch and be propelled into the air often landing one third of the map away from the original location. Now whilst not a glitch, another area for improvement with regards to character movement, is the characters constant desire to swivel when looking left or right. This movement is automated and can be rather frustrating, particularly when trying to be precise with tasks such as collecting eggs or utilising the ovoscope to check fertilisation of eggs. 
 
As a personal preference, whilst almost all of the key bindings were ideal and consistent across other games there were a few that could be improved upon, specifically when handling eggs. When collecting eggs, it is great that as the player you can hold the basket in one hand and hover over an egg on the floor/coup and select 'E' and this will automatically place the egg in the basket. However, it would be equally beneficial to have an option for taking an egg out of the basket. At present the player is required to again hover over an egg in the basket and LMB in order to pick up the highlighted egg. Whilst this is easy and quick with a full basket, this becomes more frustrating the less you have in the basket, often accidentally picking up the basket instead which is also LMB to pick up. As such, it is recommended that the action of picking up an egg from a basket is an entirely different command, and ideally could be key bound to 'Q' to remove from the basket, with 'E' remaining as the current command to place in the basket. 
 
Overall, it should be noted that the game currently remains in early access. The map is relatively bare, however there are a number of scattered buildings across the map that could serve a purpose and become interactable later down the track. As previously stated, there is a current lack in the quantity and variety of wild animals to hunt which could be a focus area to be improved upon. The addition of a recipe book and skill tree with progression benefits would be interesting to see, although more recipes and farm animals to be released should be the priority in order to maintain interest.

The game takes some time to get rolling. The tearing down of the old home is pretty tedious. I'm excited to see the updates that come. Crops, breeding horses and cows, automated machinery, and hunting are all on the horizon according to the developers. It has a great foundation. A few small bugs to be aware of are:

1. coming down the stairs in the Ranch house in the AM typically leads you to be hung up half way down
2. milking cows can have you stuck in the wall if you aren't aware of the cows orientation
3. building needs to be done on relatively flat ground or you may end up not being able to build. 
4. chickens may perch on their small feeders in the coop and not be able to get down

Maybe I am missing something but after 10 hours the only things I can do is chop trees, make them in to boards and build a house, a barn, a chicken coop and some fencing. There is no use for any other buildings really. The 3 main mats are wooden boards, concrete and metal. The other 2 you have to buy. No farming or mining or crafting. To get money you raise farm animals or hunt. By raise farm animals all you do is clean up their mess, feed and water them and thats after you buy them then sell their by products which is very limited to get money to buy more feed, metal or concrete. By hunting I mean you kill deer, bear or wolves. Thats all. All of which are few to be found and your only weapon is a 6 shooter pistol. The only thing you get from hunting is meat which you then sell for money. You will need it just to pay for the bullets.  Hunting is so limited that you can kill a deer with 2 shots from 1000 yards away (with a pistol)
 if he is standing still. My 10 hours play time could easily be done in 2 hours but I did a lot of exploring and upgrading and building large buildings just hoping to find more things to do or unlock. That never occurred. Game gets very repetitive and boring really really quick. You can upgrade saw table, water source, and vehicles but I found no reason to even need to because you can do everything required with the starting equipment. The best part about the game is character creation. It seems a lot of time and thought were put into that part of the game but little else in the game itself.

I bought this game as a Black Friday deal and wanted to check it out to change my gaming library up a little. This is the first simulation game I've played and wanted to see what all of these simulation games were about.

My original thought before purchasing this game was; it's an open world / building game based on farming. However, going into the game, my assumptions were quickly realized to be false. "Building" is essentially, "cutting" down trees, which in my opinion is very lame animation, taking said wood to a wood cutting to get wood planks. Carrying those wood planks to said "Pre-Built" structure and inserting those pieces of planks into it. Once you had all wood and/or concert, the structure is built. 

The whole "pre-built" structure to me, is a big turn-off in games, because it takes away from building creativity. 

This game itself, in the limited amount of time I played, wasn't bad. The controls are extremely weird and janky, but if you're into simulation games, I would recommend this game to you. However, this game just isn't for me.
This game has alot of potential. I would like to see some changes especially with character clothing customization.

They have come from a humble start to an epic and fun game to play. While many find bugs that are game breaking I see only fun and relaxing atmosphere. I love that they are taking the time to incorporate events that coincide with holidays and take time to answer question and take suggestions. I recommend this game to anyone who like sim type games or the like. They continue to improve the game and make things even more fun.

I do like this game and I enjoyed the time I played it. I just wish it had more to do though. It started having a feel to it of 'empty', which is not a good sign for any game to have to it. You'd want to keep them so busy and happy they lose themselves in the game play so much not to have such feelings about it.  I started feeling that playing this was just a 'killing to sell' the meat game. I'd like to see more, as in things like farming, and the like as well and the homes you build being interactable way more then now. Which is mostly just a bed, drying rack and stove. All items are only for looks which is annoying and boring. You do not need to sleep even. The fireplace has no point to it (warming or buffing... so on. Nope, No point. . Just like the rest of the items in it.) chairs you can not use.. T.V. again the same. Art board in the kids room.. same. There needs to be more point to building a house. Also more ways to make the land and home 'yours' like in things to make to place out or on walls that have your personal touch and likes/feelings to express yourself. It would make the game way more fun if there was more to the game and house. There are no buffs or anything like it in the game. No need for eating, warmth, or clothing.. so on. ( I wish it had.) The weather has no effect on the animals or you. The falling dose no damage. Not being able to plant anything is a big let down. Also with all the 'meat' you don't even need to eat it?! This game for me just lacks what is needed to feel right when playing. I have seen many others saying similar thing to this point in their posts and reviews sadly. Please add what we want and need to enjoy this on a more long term bases. It being called a 'Ranch Sim' dose not mean you can't add what rl people world have on a big plot of land. ( a farm of food for exp. (even if it's on a small scale) to eat/possibly selling. Adding it as a food mat for foods to make new recipes or add to old ones to make them even  better. You could even add it to feeders for animals as a possible alternative food source .... you name it.) For me there needs to be more to it and to do for it to work and feel right.  Adding quests btw is still not enough for me. It is still just a killing = cash game if there is not more to it. Personally I am the type that feels the need to honor and thank a animal killed for food, so this bothers me. You know, like Native Americans do. ( I know not all feel the same regarding this point.) I would need more point to this game as a whole, not just watching a baby animal grow up, only to kill it for cash. =/  That is just saddening... not fun game-play.  That in fact is why I stopped playing... for now at least. In life, like in games, there is a need for a purpose to why we do something. A means to meeting a need. What needs do we have here? Why are we sent off to kill for cash ( wild or domesticated livestock ) if not for a purpose for the kill and cash? In rl you hunt to eat. You make money off animals at a ranch to pay bills/rent and pay for your livelihood. So on. There is none of that here. No rent. No upkeep. No need for things for the player. (items like... clothes,meds,food) No needs for the player. Making that cash from the kills of the livestock then have no meanings.. right? No point. You do not eat, or use money other then buying more animals, so then no need for the meat/cheese. The purpose is what drives the game. Where is it, the purpose? That's my question. It is the 'why' we keep playing a game. To move to the next step. I'd comes back to this game again if things change for the better over all. As a whole in things to do and over all fun with some realism.  Again, I did enjoy a lot of the game because I think it had some nice ideas and game mechanics. Just not enough to stay on long term. I am looking forward to it becoming what we have been asking for at some point. Here's to hoping it does. Just listen to the buyers of this game and work with us.

This is an indie game with (I think) just one developer. So it's clunky. I'll say that right off the bat. It's also clearly designed for multiplayer, since playing it by myself often felt lonely and depressing. But still, it hooked me, and I kept coming back. 

Overall, the game mechanics are good. The goal was apparently to design a realistic farming sim, and that's what it is. You build buildings, you raise chickens, pigs, and cows, and if you make enough money at it, you can get a horse at auction. It's sad to see your animals die or decide you have to kill them to make sausage or meatballs and sell that for the money you need for feed (which the pigs, especially, go through very fast), but it feels more "down to earth" than most farm sims I've played. 

There doesn't seem to be much of an end game, yet, but the developer is still actively involved in it, so it will be interesting to see where it goes.

Its so hard for me to do this as I want to like this game. This game has SUCH potential. That said, this is basically a Gamma release and 1) is not worth what they are charging in its current form, and 2) shouldnt be on early access in this stage.

Okay so theres bugs..... Its early access, I can deal with bugs, some of them are quite funny. 

However, this game would be better off named 'Stacking Simulator'. Go to forest, cut trees, grab logs one-at-a-time. place in truck bed using poor targeting system, rinse, lather, repeat. Drive home with logs, grab logs one-at-a-time, restack at barn to cut into planks. stack planks, grab stack of planks, .... you get the picture.

The "free-build" items are.... lacking .... at best. You can build buildings, but dont build more than 2x wide as the roofs dont stack. Theres walls with holes for windows but no windows. This is a ranch sim, but no barn doors (unless you build the prefab barn...). There are no paths, so I hope you enjoy tall grass.... everywhere. You 'can' buy a lawn mower. It costs as much as a pickup truck, moves slower than walking, removes the tall grass to expose a flat, under-textured "green" area, and will use about a 1/2 tank of gas to clear a patch the size of the pickup truck.

The pre-fab buildings are.... buggy. at best. lights stop working, or just have zero impact on being able to see. Rooms are so small you can get stuck in them by opening the door to get out. close the door, move, open it, door sweeps you back to stuck.... cant get up stairs without crouching as youll get stuck on a lamp...

Vehicles are bad at best. The physics are one thing. There is no such thing as straight. You will crash into everything, and everything is a fixed point, including the deer that roam around. The most expensive pickup truck has about as much usable bed space as the gator you get for free when you start the game (and you can haul unlimited weight so....). The only point to buying different vehicles is transporting animals. The SUV is the most useless vehicle in game. Theres literally no storage. You can put a few small items on the roof rack, but you have to jump up there to be able to target the racks, and good luck jumping successfully. Game in and of itself.

Animals have massive 'space cushions'. You have to keep them indoors or else they will wander / wolves will eat them, so you build a big barn, and before you know it, animals are being forced out every time you open the door to add more food. yet when you look around theres plenty of space in the barn still. Yet the animals are "walking" but being forced in opposite directions, or just stuck, as there is some invisible buffer for the animals that seems to be 3x larger than the animal itself.

The map is tiny. It seems to be about 1 sq km. Only a small portion of this is your ranch area. Theres only 1 ranch on the map, and they just opened up multi-player, so its either co-op with your friend(s) or play single player (other farming games allow area for multiple "farms".  I imagine with a few players, you would quickly run out of buildable area on a map this small.

There are so many, many things that seem so basic for any sim game that are just missing from this game.  The road map for this came has one to two minor changes being added every other month so I doubt this game will ever meet its capabilities. 

Still a fun game, I will still play, but its getting a 4/10 from me with hopes that the Devs will up their game (both literally and figuratively)

Thumbs ALL the way up for this game. Although, collecting meat, eggs, and milk, and processing all of that can get a little mundane at times, it truly is a game that is headed for stardom. The upgrades the Devs have made so far have been nothing short of spectacular. I would like to see a wheelbarrow for the barn, possibly a shute to put in the barn for putting meat into and shooting it straight out to a pick up point instead of putting the meat in a cooler and carrying it out. This can get cumbersome when you have lots of meat. Possibly upgrades for coolers so they carry more meat would be helpful also. Also, the fences can be a bit of a challenge at times due to the terrain so it would be awesome if there were some more allowances for that. 

Otherwise, this game is awesome and addicting to play. The piglets are super cute as well as the chicks. I can't wait for the cows to be able to have calves as well. I look forward to the upcoming upgrades in the next few months. Keep it going Devs, good job!

Likes:
 - freedom to chop down any tree anywhere
 - there isn't any immediate threat of bears on the homestead
 - adding lights and obtaining illumination looks pretty good

Dislikes:
 - the fast consumption of food; i.e. chickens and egg collecting pretty much equals out, if not scrambling to obtain extra cash to obtain feed, between gas consumption costs and all
 - the selling prices. can I PLEASE have today's lumber prices??? One plank would be about 16, not the entire stack of 8 for $16. 8x16 please. Eggs should go for maybe 8-10 each, not the measly 6.
 - not enough 'inheritance' money at the start. A pathetic thousand'ish? At least double it. I had so many things go wrong in the beginning, still on the one game, working it all out...
 - CANNOT for the life of me figure out how to move an item after crafted... all I can do is destroy it and rebuild? Cmon, even the Amish can move a barn. I just want to move a table or something sensible.

Criticism/Things to ADD please:
 - More critters. It's a ranch, there's gotta be more than deer and bear. Squirrels (could run tree to tree, burying things in the ground, eating and possibly helping regrow trees!), rabbits, possums, raccoon, foxes, rats (pests).  ...and I know, it's not RDR2 or Farming Simulator, but some more wildlife would be appreciated.
 - few more guns... all I see is the revolver left in inheritance? Shotgun for bears, rifles for the deer and pests (if considered) and maybe another type of pistol or two.
 - PERKS: There is no leveling system at the moment, maybe there could be, with the selling and/or work done around the homestead? Perks like more wood planks acquired from saws, more meat upon skinning, or even upgrading the vehicles bought; handling, speed, gas consumption, etc.
 - maybe add a chainsaw? 'Insta-log' a tree with one click, chainsaw runs on gas. Why not? You have a lawn mower that is slower than anything and serves no purpose whatsoever, really.
 - AI Farmhand? We buy the feed at the store, set feed in appropriate place and farmhand can feed animals when troughs get empty. Single player or multi, that would be awesome if I didn't have to be SO attentive to the animal feed/water levels. ...maybe in future update, farmhand could be a long distant cousin (haha don't get any ideas ya hillbillies)

This game can be addicting. But for the income earned, it's almost like you even out. I started with a forest, and now have a GIGANTOR field among my homestead... lots of building space, I guess. Most of my wood was my income to get my errors corrected and keep cash flowing in. Pretty soon I'll be deforesting the town...
Not so much a chill game when time is of the essence, or chickens will starve to death.
Still recommend, want to see updates.

I understand that this game is early access, however they really do mean early. The multiplayer is alright with plenty of lagging, even with good internet speeds. There isn't much in the game in terms of progress. The animations are something you'd expect from an indie game 10 years ago. The driving physics aren't great. I'm not sure if the developers have never used most of the equipment in their life or just don't pay attention to detail. For example, the cheap table saw is gas powered, however it's clearly an electric motor that has a tube running down to a gas can. The saw blade also spins in the wrong direction and would simply kick back anything you're trying to cut. I'm sure they will improve the game throughout the next year but for now it's on par with a 2012 phone game. Not worth anywhere close to $25, maybe $10.

I know this game is early access/development stages still, but £20 you are joking. For the amount of problems it has, that’s way too expensive. I’m actually annoyed I paid that much for it.

 Pros:
* Good gameplay in terms of tasks, management, the actual storyline etc 
* Lots to do 

Cons:
* A LOT of bugs - driving mechanics are so messed up it’s near unplayable. Slightest tap to the left or right and you’re sent flying off the map. 
* The crosshair is so tiny it’s hard to interact with certain things - ie picking up the tiny eggs to put into the basket. 
* It takes so long to reload the revolver I’ve been mauled by bears several times. 
* Shooting mechanics don’t always work either, again thanks to the tiny crosshairs. 

Overall, a lot to be fixed. Primarily the driving - it’s horrendous. Don’t buy this until it’s finished is my advice.

I haven't really gotten into Ranch Simulator that much, but I can already tell it's has the possibility of being an indie gem.  If you've ever played one of the "Farming Simulator" games, and hoped for a little more than driving tractors, this could possibly be the game you've been waiting for.

Starting out with character creation, you have quite a few options to adjust your looks to set you apart from others who you might play with.  You can adjust most facial features, and even have a few body adjustments.  Clothing options are somewhat lacking, but all the available clothing is stuff you'd expect to find on a ranch.

The introduction to the ranch is really nicely done.  You start with your typical "grandfather left you a dilapidated farm" letter, which I was somewhat disappointed with due to the lack of imagination.  Like, why not have the player maybe purchased the ranch at auction or something?  You're then taken around the ranch in a very effective tutorial which quickly teaches you the basics of the game without being monotonous.  From there you assemble a small ATV, which teaches you more basics (picking up, putting down, installing objects, etc) and then you're off to visit the local shops.  There's a gas station, equipment shop, vehicle shop, country store, and a few other shops to acquire your needed items.  You even get to load the purchases into the back of your ATV to drive them back to your ranch.

Upon returning to the ranch you go through some animal husbandry stuff with your new chickens (watch it, animals escape if you don't enclose them inside something) and then you get into demolition and construction.  While the tutorial was fairly through, it left out some very basic things.  For example, I had to figure out for myself how to cut down a tree.  That said, just walking up to the tree told me what I needed to do.

This game really doesn't have the amazing graphics of other titles and camera movement (specifically first person head bobbing) can be a bit annoying.  Third person view is excellent, and can even be shifted from left to right shoulder, but the character movement seems very mechanical.  It doesn't look good.

One of the things I really did like were the color-coded waypoints that coincide with your quest objectives.  It makes it really easy to determine what objectives are where.  Animals are also well done and seem to have personality.  The animals were the high-point of the game.

While I haven't played multiplayer yet, I can well imagine it'll be enjoyable.  It functions by the primary player loading their game, then going to the pause menu (esc) and selecting to invite your friends to your ranch.  This means each person can have their own ranch (game) and you can take turns inviting friends to your ranch to help out.  Either that, or if you want a full co-op ranch you just make sure the same person hosts each time and doesn't play without the others.  It's up to you.  I didn't see an option for a dedicated server, which would allow others to play when you aren't, but it's not really a big drawback since the point of multiplayer is to play with others.

So, right about now, you're probably asking yourself "why aren't you recommending it?"  Well, even though this game is really early access and there seems to be a direction the developers are taking it, I question it's future.  There are some really important aspects of the game (like farming) which are currently missing.  Before I offer up my recommendation, I'd like to see;

- Some kind of crops, so you don't always have to buy your feed.
- A way to sell crops to the stores.
- A way to edit your world (flattening, tree planting, etc)
- More building & furniture options
- Adjustment for Time of Day (longer/shorter)

That said, I will be keeping an eye on this game to see if there are improvements in the areas I've mentioned.  The game has potential, and I really hope the developers make the best of it.

Once you finish the tutorial, it's a real challenge to figure out what to build, how to keep your chickens fed and watered etc. And driving? Man that takes getting used to. It's addictive to be sure. Looking forward to expanding my corral and getting a female pig and raising porksters.

As someone who likes to take their time, enjoy the game without caring about the newest updates and features, and generally enjoy the atmosphere, this is one of my favorite games currently. I have spent 7 and a half hours:

-Building my house
-Watching my four Chickens
-selling eggs once every 2 or 3 in-game days
-Driving around
-Listening to the radio

And these are all more than enough to make me happy. Farming Simulator and other hardcore sims about rural life just cause me stress, mostly because it feels like you do more tedious work than actual progression/game enjoyment. In Ranch Sim, there's no "do more work or lose", or pressure to always have the most amount of money. Want to build your dream house? Just chop cut and place. When you get bored of that, check on your animals. After that, refill your fuel. Or do none of the above, and simply mess around with your friends with the bat-crazy physics. 

Speaking of building, if you ever played FO76 the building is extremely similar. It's simple, clear, and not confusing at all. It is honestly my favorite part of the game. If you haven't played FO76 (I don't blame you), imagine MineCraft but instead of placing a block, you place a blueprint that you fill in at your convenience. No pressure to get it done, and you can plan amazingly far ahead before placing your first plank. Don't want to use wood? Make some money and get metal/concrete! 

And lastly, when you get sick of all the above, the game's music and ambient sounds are beautiful. I have left it running in the background for an hour just to listen to the sounds of the game, it's honestly an experience to relax to.

All that said, yeah there are of course minor issues. 

-Deconstructing anything you build returns no materials
-The radio is minimal
-There aren't a lot of animals roaming (though there are some, just not as many as I'd imagine a scene like that in the game would be there) 
-The customization of items in game are very basic and there isn't a lot of customization depth
-There is a slight content deficit, it is noticeable, but with what's in it right now it does not bother me as there are updates, they just take a while it seems to come out

But I'd lie if I said these aren't nitpicks. I barely think of these things a majority of my game time, and while it would be nice to not have to restart my game after realizing I didn't pay attention to the way the floor I just made faced after already spending the large amount of wood since deconstructing it would simply delete the now spent wood, this is more user error than the game. Not to mention, there's consistent updates and the developers obviously have plans for content, even if it is a LITTLE slow to come out. Still nice to see they don't just leave this game to the dust. 

If you don't like atmospheric-central games that have minimal guidance and leave you to your own devices and to discover what those devices are on your own, this may not be for you. But as someone who wanted a game like farming simulator without feeling that classic "Why am I spending my time doing it in a game when I could just... go do it?" This is the answer. It's relaxing, inviting, stressless, and has amazingly funny and fun physics with a beautiful building system. It was my first purchase for my new PC, and I don't regret it in the slightest.

I don't have the heart to kill the livestock, yes .. even in a game. I'd rather fish and grow food and not have to look at this horrible device in the store. On the other hand, the wild animals that attack .. I have no problem ending them if my character is cornered. Killing the animals my character nurtures and cares for .. animals who are defenseless and innocent.. not into that so much. It's sad and I don't play games to feel that way.

As for the people complaining that they can't make money, the money is in the pigs, follow this guide below

Guide: 
1. Purchase a meat grinder and sausage maker
2. Build a couple of the meat drying wardrobes
3. Buy a male and female pig (more the better)
4. Let them keep breeding and growing old and fat (They multiply like crazy)
5. Make the sausages but do not boil them, instead use the drying wardrobes
6. This will make pork sausages (Salami), visit the burger place every morning to check the multipliers, wait until you get x1.9 or x2 multipliers offered for them and then sell them.

Hope this helps some people as i just made $45K doing this

I'm 8 hours into this game and can honestly say I'm loving it. With that said, I will also point out at the time of this review its still very early access. This is not a game to be "won" in a few hours, it is definitely a grind in the beginning. However, I find it really satisfying when I finally save enough money to buy the next animal I want or the materials I need for my next building. 

The developers are very active about adding more content and updating the game, I'm particularly looking forward to the hunter/farm quests that are planned. There are a few bugs and there's no consequences for collision damage or fall damage. The only thing so far that has really annoyed me, is how much it takes to feed chickens and how little you get in return from them.  I would like it implemented in the future that if you allow them out of their coop, they can satisfy their hunger a portion through that.

Shifting shop prices would be another fun element to eventually implement and the need to eat/drink for your main character. The graphics, in my opinion, are spot on. I can only run them at Medium on my laptop so I can only imagine how gorgeous this is with Epic settings. I haven't yet played this with any friends so the grind to build and make money is real as a single player.

I'll probably update this review when some more updates come out and I have quite a few more hours into it. But as of right now, I highly recommend the game. There may be bugs and its pretty bare-bones with NPC's, but the core of it is very enjoyable.

I bought this for myself for my birthday, I'd seen gameplay through a YouTuber named Drae and really liked what I saw but he didn't play with the horse update, so I was excited when I saw the horses. I have a lot of things I think would be cool in the game, but I know there's only so much the devs can do at once right now, and am excited for the new roadmap that came out recently (October animal naming, and some stuff with the multiplayer mode, which I wanna play multiplayer but my friends don't have the game, December has a new cow coming with cow breeding for it and fattening of the cow and automilking machine, February has some stuff I can't remember right now). 

At first I struggled, and I wish I dicvoered the coolers sooner, but I didn't, as well as sausage production. But at first I had 2 hens and a rooster, which, died while I was focusing on my barn as I never realized they didn't have enough food. I was broke, but selling the raw chicken and their eggs I had collected I had enough for a single hen. I finished my barn and began selling wooden planks and eventually got my first pig. Then things changed a lot. That pig doubled how much I paid for it and I had enough for 2 pigs, which I've only seen upward progress since then. 

I'm working on building a massive barn, just need to do the stables in it and then light it and build a granary and I plan to use it for horses. I'll probably expand my current one for cows, as I finally got my second cow and had to move my horse to a small pen inside the barn I had made for my chicken originally.

Maybe add cow horses, cutting horses, some reining and maybe even some cattle sorting to really give it a more ranch feel.

I initially was having fun with the game. and overall it is fun. however the more I played the more frustrated I got. Making money seems near impossible. They give you about $1000 and 2 chickens to start out after the tutorial. Selling 6 eggs gets me $24 then food for the chickens cost 30...literally loosing money faster than i can make money. 
The hunting is supposed to be another way to make money however you have to be like 5 feet from the animal to actually get a hit on it. Any farther away and your character seems to just not know how to aim and bullets hit the ground around the animal even when your aiming directly at it and its not moving. After wasting several bullets trying to hunt one deer I had to buy more...I made $45 from the meat. and then had to spend $40 on bullets...only making $5 profit.
Pigs are apparently supposed to be the best way to make money however you have to build a barn and silo and metal for the doors and silo isnt cheap. after building the barn and still taking care of the chickens i have no money to buy metal to build the silo let alone $300 for each pig. the only way I've seen people actually making money in this game is by using a cheat engine. 

it would be an even better game...if they fixed the money making system and hunting.

The community pushed for stick built custom buildings and the development team jumped in action and in what a month gave it to us.  This one is a gem that is just going to get better.
Like

Overall, I knew what I was getting into this game after watching YouTubers like Drae play for the past couple of weeks. I was excited for this game and was ready for it to be out of early access. I can say after 7 and a half hours of gameplay, it's still excites me to see the new updates planned. Do I think the game is worth $19.99? At this state, I'd say it's worth maybe $15.99 or $14.99. It's very fun so far but it does feel very empty as of right now. I'd rather wait until the April update of Daily quests and stuff to green light this. But I paid the $19 because I'm impatient and idc, I'm still just chilling with my chickens. This game is not perfect, and still has some bit a ways to go for it to reach its full potential. But the money-managing, farm-sim. Is still an okay game in my book.

Some Bugs I Noticed:
-Even in Drae's games on YT and some people here bring up that the autofeeders and grain silo do not work, and i can say that they do not work for me either and almost cost me an animal
-Deluxe coop does not have an autofeeder, which was disappointing
-Sometimes the deer will not drop after two shots.
-Cow and pigs will get their heads stuck on the side of the barn from the insides
-Sometimes eggs will not drop into the egg drawer in the coop. (I mean the unfertilized ones)
-Another bug as of 3/9/21 my eggs disappeared from my basket after loading the save.

What I Would Love to See in The Game Going Forward
-More cow colors/breeds like the Simmental, Belted Galloway, and the Holstein
-More chicken breeds like Silkie, Plymouth Rock Chicken
-We see more Sheep breeds
-More farm animal breeds in general even if they are just recolours.
- A vehicle marker would be VERY helpful on the map.
-Dogs and cats, cats could remove rodents that eat the grain, and dogs would chase off predators like foxes, bears, and coyotes that kill chickens or steal their eggs.
-We see more predator animals or wildlife like foxes tat sneak into hen houses, eagles that steal chicks, fish.
-We have fishing in a game, fishing is something that could be added to a way to earn money.
-Vehicle damage and better steering controls. With the amount of videos and times I ran into trees maybe some consequence would be you have to repair this vehicle, but the steering needs to be more manageable first.
-Breeding systems for sheep, cows, and horses
-Maybe some type of inventory menu showing the amount of grain you have, meat you found, etc.
-Highway lamps for night (even if they are scarce or spaced out)
-House decoration, remodels.
-Maybe a hen barn, some farms do not have small hutches or outside farms irl, instead they have huge chicken barns to house their animals, They have bedding, nest boxes, sandpits, I'd say check it out, it's pretty cool. Same thing with cows, not all cows live in big red barns, some are on feedlots and in other types of housing.
-Electronic milkers for the cows
-More townspeople, rival farms, more shopkeepers, days where the stores aren't open. People come to your farm to ask favors, buy products directly from you. Make the small area seem more alive.
-This can follow above, but have like a  delivery man to deliver animals you may buy online or deliver quest items to a town over (if you make it so you can't visit the town). 
-Maybe, future DLC maps or a secondary town, I noticed the bridge tunnel and maybe you can travel there to buy another ranch or different animals, or meet more rivals.
-Have deluxe coop (I think that's the one with drawers), be able to allow you to enter and clean the poop.
-Also for the health bar on animals? Get a town vet and have the animals be able to come down with sickness. Did you quarantine your animal in a stall or separate hutch? Well your whole flock/herd got sick. Make sure to buy some medicine

Again this game for me is pretty fun and something I can play to relax if need be. I don't expect everyone to like it, or my review on it and that's cool. I'll update my review as new additions are added and I will change around some things as it comes. Whether you think this price tag is good for early access, that's also up to you, I'd recommend looking at game play before purchasing and  make that decision for yourself. I also know my wants may never come to fruition and that's also fine, I just hope the gameplay becomes more immersive and still continues being fun.

Downloaded this game. Created my character. All was well until I went to lower my graphics from "epic" to "high." Had to reboot the game for the graphics change to take effect, then it blue screened my laptop three times. Never could get back on the game, so I refunded it.

Loving it so far, very excited to see what is added in the future!!

7/10 Overall

Graphics- 8/10 Art Style is realistic and well done. Love was put into the models. That said, its a bit grainy and I cant seem to get above 44ish frames.
Sound- 9/10 Lots of really good music on the radio stations and clear crisp sounds. Would like varied animal noises.
Story- 3/10 Very good introduction. I can see there easily being more than the 10 or so quests that are currently in the game. A few more fetch quests to get money for early game would make early game a LOT more bearable.
Game-play- 8/10 Having both pre-made buildings and the ability to make your own from scratch allows for a lot of creativity without it being too daunting.
Customization- 9/10 Character customization is very in depths besides the small amount of hairstyles. 
Play Time- Solo you can probably do 20 hrs before boredom really sets in. With a group I'd say a lot more.

Overall I adore the game and can't wait to see more items/animals (CROPS???) in the game!!

Decent Sim Game

From the get-go, this game was a pleasant but buggy experience for me. While I may only have about 15 minutes of gameplay in this, it's enough to tell that currently, at ~$20  AUD, this game is overpriced. 

Ranch Simulator feels generally underpolished, buggy (one of the first bugs you will notice is how badly a car will react physics-wise when hitting a rock. I understand this is a game, but it certainly does not feel realistic.

There is no hunger, no pain, no real NPC dialogue that matters. No story, really. It's essentially just build a farm, bigger and bigger. It seems like this needs to be in alpha longer, even before it is released as early access. Currently the game is worth, to me (and this is honest in comparison to games like house flipper, thief simulator, etc.) around $5. It is certainly not an enjoyable experience personally, but I'll let it be up to you to decide whether or not to spend your money on this frankly underwhelming game (something I do not recommend).

The game is a lot of fun to play. Some bugs that need fixing, but nothing game breaking. The building in the game is also very simple and easy to do. Managing the animals is challenging at times, leave a gate open and they escape when they can. The only thing i hope for is that there is not going to be a true survival mechanism, some basic things like drinking and eating is ok. For true survival mechanims there are plenty of other games to play for that. Now the game is just relaxing fun, taking care of the animals, upgrading their buildings, breeding, selling etc. I recommend the game for everyone that is just looking for a fun and relaxing farm building/management game.

I think this is a pretty good game despite some lack of appearance quality, and lack of information/description on items and practices after the tutorial.
Things I Like:
The Animal AI to return to the coop/barn at night
Checking if chicken eggs are fertilized with the Ovoscope(light)
Hens attacking sometimes when you pick up the eggs
Leading Cows home if you don't have a vehicle to transport them
Milking actually using A and D button presses to milk
The variety of chicken coops
The Character models and movements are great, even though they feel like a pre-made asset store system.

What I DON'T like:
The game looks kind of bad even with a great game engine like Unreal Engine.
No terrain painting, grass stays inside barn.
Map feels low effort, could use more attention instead of just tree and rock brushing.
The UI for the stores, particularly the lack of information on products. Why is there two kinds of metal bucket???
Cows don't Graze. I have a big open pasture for them to wander, so they should eat grass.
Lack of fence variety. I need different fences to use around the farm.
No Farming crops. We should be able to grow/cut our own animal feed.
Just one type of barn, with no alternate options for modular pieces. 
No predators as far as I've seen aside from Bears on the other side of the map. Ranch animals are too Safe.

Wow that's a lot of gripes, and that wasn't the end of it. However, I DO recommend this game as you will have fun with it for a while!

Keeping in mind I fully understand this is an EA game. I do have some regrets about making this purchase. It can be a great game and the graphics are very good. The realistic weather is cool and the scenery is great. However the balance is off. I understand it is meant to be a simulation but it takes WAY TOO LONG to get anything done, very grindy. To make any kind of money to start you either hunt (very little yield or profit compared to expense) sell eggs (chickens burn through feed like its free so really not worth it) cut trees and make into wood boards (cut a tree, carry 1 log, cut to 2 planks, rinse and repeat) that yields little cash. When you demolish something you do not gain even 1 resource to use towards a new build, that doesn't make sense. I tear things down all the time and reuse what I demo, not all of it but at least 30%. It's a good thing you don't have to eat or drink or you would die all the time because you spend so much time just trying to make $150 only to spend $90 doing it for a profit of $60 to go towards building your ranch up. I like a challenging game but I also do not have 60 hours a week to get a good start. I would wait until more updates come and the devs figure out more balance. Maybe allow some jobs with the abandon surrounding ranches like tearing stuff down or fixing stuff so you can make a bit more cash without expending more resources trying to do so (like people do, ya know). Want to sell sausage or cheese? First you need about $500 to even start that process. Horses are 2500 and a good vehicle is 1600 (realistic but it will take 30 hours of game play to get there). Neat idea but I regret my purchase..........

DO NOT buy this game yet, even when on sale.

Ranch Sim at the moment is all about killing every animal you see, then selling their meat. After 16 hours of play my main daily focus is all about the hunting/killing.

I have tried to raise and breed chickens (8) and pigs (2) with my hard earned hunting (blood Money). However, the cost of keeping them watered and fed seems to take all the money I have and I am constantly hunting just to keep the chickens and pigs alive.

As for wanting to building my own dream Ranch house from wood that I have painstakingly gathered from chopping down trees and making into planks. I did this only to find that I can't get any furniture for it! What is the point of an empty house, why did the developers give me the ability to build something I can't live in? Hence why I am still sleeping in the tent I got given at the start of the game.

I can though build/select a house from a build catalogue of template houses. Which do come completely furnished, the only down side is it costs lots of money to buy the resources needed to create them, money which I don't have because every animal I killed is helping me keep the 8 chickens and 2 pigs alive.

Good news though, I see the latest patch introduced Horses (woohoo). Just what I need when struggling to survive and living in a tent next to my 8 chickens and 2 pigs. It costs $50 just to go to Horse auction and then on arrival if you have a spare $5000 - $6000 you can bid for one.

Really, is it me, or did the developers completely miss the point?

This game should be called "Hobo Hunter" not "Ranch Simulator".

I've been playing this game almost every day. So many aspects of the game are exceptional; the fact that I can simply build, cut logs to build, gather eggs, make sausages and preserve meat, then sell and repeat the process is relaxing. Caring for animals gives me a way to unwind from a busy day. The lack of pressure to complete missions or fend my ranch from predators or other "dire" consequences is very refreshing. No pressure to use your gun unless you choose to. The crafting is intelligently put together, the majority of what I've encountered about this game's design makes logical sense. 

The August update which includes horses feels like this game is becoming a dream come true. If the horses activities and care for them are as quality a process as for the other animals in this game, then this game will definitely be in my top list of quality adult horse games (which are VERY FEW in the gaming world at the moment).

Also, while the 3D models in this game (cows and deer specifically) could definitely use some work, as it is in Early Access I'm assuming these will be improving over time. Hoping the horses will look believable and realistic as well!

Overall I'm very happy with this game and eagerly anticipating everything to come. Keep this amazing thing going devs!

I grew up on a cattle farm.  This game takes me back to those days.  In game I have fallen into my old routines.  take care of the animals when that is done work on repair and maintenance of the buildings and equipment. When I first bought the game I read a few reviews saying that the game runs poorly, controls are wonky, the driving mechanics are not very good, etc. This game runs great, good control setup, and the driving mechanics are good enough for you to go hunting/selling your products. Although it does lack some content after you start to get your pigs, cows, and chickens going although you are constantly making sure they are fed/watered. Hopefully they add the new animals that are listed in the store, some more tools, and possibly some new buildings to work towards getting. I am going to give this game a 8/10 for gameplay and constantly keeping you busy while somehow still being fun instead of feeling like work like you'd expect of a Ranch Simulator. The developers seem to be active in releasing update notes and keeping up with the community, so hopefully they listen to all of us and add the things we want in the game. In conclusion I would definitely buy this game and give it a try.

Considering this game is early access, its got a great start. The online multiplayer option makes the game SO much more fun. There is an in game radio that has various bits of music me and my husband find pretty entertaining while working on the ranch and just driving around. We have made various ramps for the different vehicles in the game which has been pretty fun on top of the actual ranch style game. The car mechanics can be very glitchy especially with the small trailer while backing up. Honestly find it funny more then anything at times. At first making money feels tedious and you have to really start small and work your ranch up, which I didn't mind too much. The graphics are screenshot worthy and the game is just overall so entertaining to play. Hoping they add some more modifications to the vehicles and maybe some better building options. But overall its a pretty fun game. They also have a very active discord page where you can ask questions and leave suggestions and all sorts of other game related topics which is also really nice.

It's not bad. The driving is kinda janky and not realistic at all. They really need to up the content, or something. It's kinda odd that the only way to make any real money is to hunt, and that's just not abundant enough. I can take time cutting down trees, spend fuel hauling the logs, cutting them in to lumber, and driving them to the store to sell them, and they're only worth $1 each? Also, if I'm able to cut my own trees, make my own planks, etc., why do I have to buy things like the chicken coop, fences, doors for the barn, etc. instead of building them myself.  Isn't "builder" one of their advertised "jobs"? It kinda kills the whole point of most of the activities they give you. I'm also not a big fan of being limited on where I can place buildings, etc. I prefer freedom. Other than that, it's fun. I'll recommend it cause it's cheap, and you'll definitely get your money's worth.

First this game is way overpriced for the content that is available, but even if, all the content that seems to be coming soon, I would still say it is overpriced. I have played about 20 hrs. and petty much bought and produced everything in the game at about 12hrs.  

Good: 

I like the concept of the game 

Items you can build are easy to place and remove 

Nice music 

Cutting and making planks are exactly right, tree cutting great, and the saw works fine 

Making cheese works fine, the racks for drying are fine. 

Bad: 

The graphics are generic “bought on an online store” 

Driving sucks, why does every game like to use WASD keys to drive, the mouse is the way to go. 

Removing items is fast and easy, sometimes too easy. Try to remove a bucket or anything while in a built house or barn because one miss and the whole house/barn is destroyed. No warning! 

Destroying buildings returns you nothing, not even 50% of cost of wood or metal. 

Ugly: 

To produce a sausage you must raise and pig/cow/chicken, kill it, pick every piece of meat (one to 15 pieces) place it in a cooler, move it to the grinder, pick up a piece, place it in the grinder, grind it into a pot, pick the pot, put it the sausage maker, take the sausage and hang it a room to dry, when dry, take the sausage place it in the cooler and then sell it. You can skip the drying process and sell it raw. If this was not ugly enough, they place the drying rack in such a way to make it hard to place the sausage. Also, in some houses a door might block your way which needs to be open and closed every time you hang and unhang sausage. You may bypass all this buy building in the cement garage, which is in on your farm, but it has draw backs too; you must cut and buy metal to produce the tables and drying racks. But you still need the farmhouse for the stove. 

When you first buy the grinder and sausage maker, it’s manual, you must turn a crank by moving your mouse in a circle (the well works the same way), WOW what Dev thought that was a great idea? Do that twice for every sausage made and it gets old fast! 

Let us not talk about the eggs 

I understand this game is in early access, that is ok, it also should be $10 too. Most of the stuff could be solved by giving more access to improve machines later in the game to cut out the many stepping points. I would recommend this to people who have money to spend and like the pain. But currently, I do not recommend this game to all the rest. I will come back in a few game updates and add to this review.

Thanks Developers for your hard and dedicated work of bringing us Ranch Simulator!

Early access vs finished product. I am super happy i bought the early access before the real game due to the changes myself and the rest of the community can hopefully have effect on. This isn't a positive nor negative review, but a honest one. I paid for this game for both my wife and myself. We have played it through twice now, and the comments from others in the community about it being mostly a meat, cheese, and multiplier farming is the reality so far. There isn't much past that.

    There Is no real competitive adversity. Nothing to keep you on edge just the sleep and repeat. The biggest worries you have is animal fatality's and time management. Also once you finish acquiring the all the vehicles, houses, and animal facilities your left with the sudden fall off of entertainment. Its hard to maintain peak interest when you so easily have it all and have no further goals. the reality of this game is its not a ranch sim yet.

    Now after that potion of my review i want to reiterate this is not a negative nor positive review. This game is in early access and not yet finished in fact if the creators care for this game as much; if not more than the community whom gets to share what they've created. This game has much yet to come to light.

   Chickens, Pigs, Cows, and others not yet available. These are the bread and butter so to speak of this game and provide a need of constant attention, the animals all have there unique qualities. There are a few shops that have many items for sale. Gas is a constant need for your character and your pursuit through the game. It has well balanced mechanics. The building mechanics is in my opinion similar to "The Forest". The mechanics are very balanced between what you can obtain on your own vs what you need to acquire form the stores. all in all this game has a ability to be extremely advanced or under developed.

    To the developers i hope you have the opportunity to read this and make a quick response it would be appreciated to see you do follow what is being posted on your feed.  As a real life construction worker and rancher i believe you have something here to envy and nurture. Some suggestions to take or leave. A actual town setting. More Agriculture on the ranch. (Ranchers try to grow what there livestock eat, when they can.) Diversity in needs for animal food consumption. A real adversity for the player such as hunger, thirst, building deterioration (fencing), natural disasters, and even wild animal attacks on livestock. Missions and goals to achieve. (even the poorest farmer has a daily goal that gets him to tomorrow). Veterinarian visits and cost.

    Thank you all for the thoughts and time you've spent to read this. My wife and I have had a great time writing this and are continue to play.
